title: Quiz 2: Medical Surgical Nursing
topicName: NCK Paper 1 Anatomy and Physiology Questions
description: Medical Surgical Nursing MCQs covering chronic conditions, acute care interventions, and patient education.

questions.question: A patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is experiencing respiratory distress. Which nursing intervention is the priority for managing the patient's respiratory status?

options.text: Positioning the patient in high Fowler's position

questions.explanation: Positioning is the priority independent nursing action. High Fowler's position allows for maximum chest expansion and diaphragmatic excursion, providing immediate mechanical relief for breathing. Medications require orders or time to work.
questions.hint: Think about mechanical interventions that maximize lung expansion immediately.

questions.question: A patient post-thyroidectomy develops signs of hypocalcemia, including tingling around the mouth and muscle cramps. Which action should the nurse take first?

options.text: Encourage increased intake of dairy products

questions.explanation: Symptomatic hypocalcemia (tetany, laryngospasm risk) is a medical emergency post-thyroidectomy. The nurse must notify the provider immediately to obtain an order for IV Calcium Gluconate.
questions.hint: This is a potential airway emergency requiring immediate medical intervention.

questions.question: A patient with a history of heart failure presents with dependent edema in the lower extremities. Which nursing action is most appropriate for managing the patient's edema?

options.text: Elevating the legs above heart level

questions.explanation: Elevating the legs promotes venous return through gravity, reducing dependent edema. While diuretics are the medical treatment, leg elevation is the primary nursing action for symptom management.
questions.hint: Use gravity to assist venous return.

questions.question: A patient with a history of diabetes mellitus is admitted with a foot ulcer. Which nursing intervention is essential for preventing infection in the foot ulcer?

options.text: Keeping the ulcer covered with a sterile dressing

questions.explanation: A sterile dressing acts as a barrier against environmental pathogens, maintaining a clean wound bed. Debridement is a specialized procedure, not routine nursing preventative care.
questions.hint: Think about the primary way to block environmental pathogens from entering a wound.

questions.question: A patient with a history of cirrhosis is at risk for developing hepatic encephalopathy. Which nursing intervention is most effective in preventing and managing hepatic encephalopathy?
questions.explanation: Lactulose acts as a laxative and acidifies the gut lumen, trapping ammonia (as ammonium) and promoting its excretion in stool. This is the gold standard pharmaceutical intervention to lower serum ammonia levels.
questions.hint: This medication traps ammonia in the gut for excretion.

questions.question: A patient with a history of stroke is at risk for impaired skin integrity due to immobility. Which nursing intervention is most effective in preventing pressure ulcers in this patient?

options.text: Turning and repositioning the patient every 2 hours
Applying heating pads to areas of erythema

questions.explanation: Regular repositioning relieves prolonged pressure on bony prominences, restoring blood flow to tissues. This is the single most effective nursing intervention.
questions.hint: Relieving pressure physically is more effective than any device or massage.

questions.question: A patient with a history of chronic kidney disease is prescribed a low-phosphorus diet. Which dietary choice indicates understanding of the prescribed diet?

options.text: Whole wheat toast with peanut butter

questions.explanation: Patients with CKD must avoid foods high in phosphorus. Cheese/dairy, whole grains/nuts, and peanut butter are high in phosphorus. White meat like chicken breast is a lower phosphorus protein choice.
questions.hint: Dairy, nuts, and whole grains are typically high in phosphorus.

questions.question: A patient with a history of peptic ulcer disease is prescribed proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) for ulcer healing. Which information is important for the nurse to include in patient education about PPI therapy?

options.text: PPIs should be taken on an empty stomach.
PPIs should be discontinued once symptoms resolve.
PPIs may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
PPIs should be taken with antacids for optimal effect.

questions.explanation: PPIs (e.g., omeprazole) are most effective when taken 30-60 minutes before the first meal of the day (breakfast) to inhibit the proton pumps activated by food intake.
questions.hint: This medication needs to be in the system before food stimulates acid production.

questions.question: A patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is prescribed a metered-dose inhaler (MDI) with a spacer. Which instruction should the nurse include in the demonstration of MDI use?

options.text: Inhale slowly and deeply while pressing the canister.
Exhale completely before inhaling the medication.
Shake the inhaler vigorously before each puff.
Hold the breath for 10 seconds after inhaling the medication.

questions.explanation: Proper MDI technique involves a slow, deep inhalation to carry the medication deep into the lungs rather than impacting the throat. While other steps are involved, the coordination of actuation and inhalation is critical.
questions.hint: How should the patient breathe in to ensure the mist reaches the lower airways?

questions.question: A patient with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus is prescribed insulin glargine (Lantus) once daily. Which statement indicates understanding of insulin glargine administration?

options.text: I will inject insulin glargine 30 minutes before meals.
I will shake the insulin vial vigorously before drawing the dose.
I will rotate injection sites within the same body region.
I will administer insulin glargine with a rapid-acting insulin.

questions.explanation: Rotation of sites prevents lipodystrophy. Glargine is a long-acting basal insulin given at the same time daily, regardless of meals. It should not be mixed or shaken.
questions.hint: This practice prevents the formation of fatty lumps under the skin.

questions.question: A patient with a history of heart failure is prescribed digoxin. Which assessment finding indicates a potential adverse effect of digoxin therapy?
questions.explanation: Digoxin slows AV node conduction. Bradycardia (Heart Rate < 60 bpm) is a primary sign of toxicity requiring pulse assessment before administration.
questions.hint: Digoxin strengthens force but slows the rate of the heart.

questions.question: A patient with a history of coronary artery disease is prescribed aspirin for antiplatelet therapy. Which information is important for the nurse to include in patient education about aspirin therapy?

options.text: Take aspirin with a full glass of milk to minimize gastrointestinal upset.
Avoid using nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) while taking aspirin.
Discontinue aspirin therapy if you develop a fever.
Take aspirin on an empty stomach for better absorption.

questions.explanation: Aspirin is a gastric irritant. Taking it with food or milk helps protect the gastric mucosa.
questions.hint: Aspirin is an acid that can irritate the stomach lining.

questions.question: A patient with a history of stroke is prescribed clopidogrel (Plavix) for secondary prevention of thrombotic events. Which laboratory test should the nurse monitor closely during clopidogrel therapy?
questions.explanation: Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet agent. Monitoring for signs of low platelets or Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP) is relevant.
questions.hint: This drug works by inhibiting platelet aggregation.

questions.question: A patient with a history of chronic kidney disease is prescribed erythropoietin-stimulating agents (ESAs) for anemia management. Which parameter should the nurse monitor closely during ESA therapy?
questions.explanation: The goal of ESA therapy is to raise hemoglobin, but excessively high levels (>11 g/dL) increase cardiovascular risks.
questions.hint: What blood component does erythropoietin stimulate?

questions.question: A patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is prescribed prednisone for an acute exacerbation. Which instruction is important for the nurse to include in patient education about prednisone therapy?

options.text: Take prednisone with antacids to minimize gastrointestinal upset.
Increase your intake of potassium-rich foods while taking prednisone.
Prednisone may cause weight loss, so monitor your weight regularly.

questions.explanation: Systemic corticosteroids suppress the adrenal glands. Abrupt cessation can lead to an acute Addisonian crisis (adrenal insufficiency).
questions.hint: The body's natural production of this hormone stops when taking it exogenously.

questions.question: A patient with a history of chronic kidney disease is prescribed a low-protein diet. Which dietary choice indicates understanding of the prescribed diet?
questions.explanation: In CKD, protein should be restricted but of High Biological Value (HBV) like fish or poultry, which produce less nitrogenous waste than plant proteins or red meats.
questions.hint: Look for a high-quality protein source that is not red meat.

questions.question: A patient with a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is prescribed warfarin therapy. Which instruction is essential for the nurse to include in patient education about warfarin therapy?

options.text: Limit your intake of green leafy vegetables.
Avoid activities that may increase your risk of bleeding.
Take a double dose if you miss a dose to catch up.
Report any unusual bleeding or bruising to your healthcare provider.

questions.explanation: Bleeding is the primary risk. Patients should avoid contact sports and injury risks. Note: Patients should maintain consistent Vitamin K intake, not strictly limit it.
questions.hint: Anticoagulants prevent clots but increase the risk of the opposite problem.

questions.question: A patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is prescribed tiotropium (Spiriva) inhaler. Which instruction should the nurse include in patient education about tiotropium inhaler use?

options.text: Use the inhaler only when you experience symptoms.
Rinse your mouth with water after each use.
Exhale forcefully before inhaling the medication.
Store the inhaler in the refrigerator between uses.

questions.explanation: For Dry Powder Inhalers (DPI), the patient must empty their lungs away from the device before inhaling deeply to ensure the powder reaches the lungs.
questions.hint: You need empty lungs to take a full breath of medication.

questions.question: A patient with a history of myocardial infarction is prescribed atorvastatin for lipid-lowering therapy. Which parameter should the nurse monitor closely during atorvastatin therapy?
questions.explanation: Statins can cause hepatotoxicity. Routine monitoring of liver enzymes (AST/ALT) is recommended.
questions.hint: Statins are metabolized by and can affect this major organ.

questions.question: A patient with a history of heart failure is prescribed lisinopril for blood pressure management. Which adverse effect is most commonly associated with lisinopril therapy?
questions.explanation: A persistent, dry, non-productive cough is the most common side effect of ACE inhibitors like lisinopril due to bradykinin accumulation.
questions.hint: This respiratory side effect is specific to ACE inhibitors.

questions.question: A patient with a history of peptic ulcer disease is prescribed famotidine (Pepcid) for gastric acid suppression. Which instruction should the nurse include in patient education about famotidine therapy?

options.text: Take famotidine on an empty stomach.
Avoid taking antacids while on famotidine therapy.
Increase your intake of spicy foods while taking famotidine.
Notify your healthcare provider if you develop black, tarry stools.

questions.explanation: Black, tarry stools (melena) indicate gastrointestinal bleeding, suggesting the ulcer is worsening or the medication is ineffective.
questions.hint: This symptom indicates bleeding in the upper GI tract.

questions.question: A patient with a history of stroke is prescribed aspirin and clopidogrel for dual antiplatelet therapy. Which nursing intervention is essential for preventing bleeding complications in this patient?

options.text: Providing education on fall prevention measures

questions.explanation: Monitoring for signs of low platelets (bruising, petechiae) or Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (associated with Plavix) is critical.
questions.hint: This condition involves a low count of the cells responsible for clotting.

questions.question: A patient with a history of chronic kidney disease is prescribed phosphate binders. Which instruction should the nurse include in patient education about phosphate binder therapy?

options.text: Avoid taking phosphate binders with calcium supplements.
Increase your intake of foods high in phosphorus.
Take phosphate binders on an empty stomach.

questions.explanation: Phosphate binders must bind with phosphorus in the food while it is in the GI tract to prevent absorption. They are ineffective if taken on an empty stomach.
questions.hint: The drug needs to mix with food to work.

questions.question: A patient with a history of coronary artery disease is scheduled for coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery. Which preoperative nursing intervention is essential for preparing the patient for surgery?

options.text: Providing education about postoperative pain management
Assisting the patient with deep breathing and coughing exercises
Obtaining informed consent for the surgical procedure

questions.explanation: Preoperative teaching of deep breathing, coughing, and splinting is a critical intervention to prevent postoperative pulmonary complications like atelectasis.
questions.hint: This teaching prevents lung complications after chest surgery.

questions.question: A patient with a history of heart failure is prescribed a beta-blocker. Which assessment finding indicates a therapeutic effect of beta-blocker therapy?
questions.explanation: Beta-blockers reduce sympathetic outflow, lowering heart rate and myocardial oxygen demand, which allows for better diastolic filling in heart failure.
questions.hint: Beta-blockers 'block' the stimulation that speeds up the heart.
